summary: The homeowner submitted an application to the Tribunal.  The Tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner failed to provide the required information and documentation.
key_quote: The basis of the decision is that the Applicant has failed to comply with Rule 5 and Rule 43 and Section 17 of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner complained about Homesbook Factoring Ltd breaching the Code of Conduct and their duties. The tribunal ordered Homesbook to pay £500 in respect of inconvenience caused and to prepare a schedule of proposed staff training.
key_quote: Within 14 days of the date of service of this PFEO the respondent must pay the applicant £ 500 in respect of inconvenience caused to him and additionally return any late payment charges still due to be refunded.

summary: The applicant filed an application with the tribunal. However, the applicant failed to provide requested information by the given deadlines. Consequently, the tribunal rejected the application.
The homeowner submitted an application to the Tribunal, but failed to comply with the rules. The Tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner did not provide necessary information.
key_quote: The basis of the decision is that the Applicant has failed to comply with Rule 5 and Rule 43 and Section 17 of the 2011 Act.

summary: The applicant submitted an application to the tribunal but failed to provide the required information. The tribunal rejected the application because of this failure.
key_quote: Accordingly the Tribunal have good reason to believe that it would not be appropriate to accept the application and reject the application in terms of rule 8 (1)(c) of the Tribunal Rules.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application, but failed to provide required information and documentation.  The tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner did not comply with rules and the 2011 Act.
key_quote: The basis of the decision is that the Applicant has failed to comply with Rule 5 and Rule 43 and Section 17 of the 2011 Act.

summary: The applicant's application was rejected because the applicant did not provide the requested information to the tribunal. The tribunal determined that it would not be appropriate to accept the application.
The applicant submitted an application which the tribunal rejected. The tribunal requested further information from the applicant, but the information was not provided.
The Tribunal rejected the application because the applicant did not provide the requested information, despite having sufficient opportunity to do so.
The tribunal rejected the application because the applicant did not provide the information requested. The applicant had sufficient opportunity to provide the information.
The homeowner filed an application with the tribunal. The tribunal requested more information from the applicant, which was not provided, leading to the application's rejection.
key_quote: The Applicant has not provided the information requested and has had sufficient opportunity to do so.

summary: The applicant failed to provide requested information. The tribunal rejected the application due to the lack of response and information.
key_quote: The applicant has not responded to the two emails dated 22 October 2020 and 20 November 2020 and the requested information has not been provided.

summary: The applicant's application was rejected due to a failure to provide requested information. The Tribunal issued two emails requesting further information, but the applicant did not respond.
key_quote: The Tribunal rejects the application by the applicant dated 18 September 2020 being an application under section 17(1) of the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011.

summary: The homeowner filed an application with the tribunal. The tribunal requested further information from the applicant, but the applicant did not respond. The tribunal rejected the application.
key_quote: The Applicant has not provided the information requested and has had sufficient opportunity to do so.

summary: The tribunal rejected the application because the applicant failed to sign and date the application form as requested.

The homeowner complained about the factor's poor communication, and delays in addressing water ingress and communal repairs. The tribunal upheld the complaint, finding breaches of the Code related to communication and maintenance and awarded compensation.
key_quote: The Factor has failed to carry out its property Factor's duties.

summary: The homeowner complained about the charges for roof repairs and alleged failures to comply with the Code of Conduct. The tribunal found that the property factor had complied with the Code and had not failed to carry out the property factor’s duties.
key_quote: It seemed to members of the tribunal that, although the Applicant and the Property Factor had differing views on the issues about management of the Property, it was a matter of interpretation and not their credibility.

summary: The homeowner complained that the factor was in breach of the Code. The tribunal decided to dismiss the application because the factor had written off the alleged debt and it was not a good use of judicial time to consider the application further.
key_quote: The substantive issue was that the Factor was claiming that a debt was due by the Homeowner following the termination of its services. This had been disputed by the Homeowner on a number of grounds.

summary: The homeowner filed an application with the tribunal. The tribunal requested additional information from the applicant, which was not provided. As a result, the application was rejected.
key_quote: The applicant has not provided the Tribunal with the information requested namely evidence that the breach of section 6.2 of the Code of Conduct has been notified to the Factor and also a copy of the Written Statement of services.

summary: The applicant made a complaint regarding breaches of the Code of Conduct and Property Factor Duties. The tribunal rejected the application due to the applicant failing to provide the requested information.
key_quote: The Tribunal rejects the application by the Applicant dated 1st March 2020, being an application under section 17(1) of the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011.

summary: The homeowner made an application regarding compliance with the Fire (Scotland) Act 2005 and the Fire Safety (Scotland) Regulations 2006. The tribunal determined that the application was not relevant and was rejected.
key_quote: The Tribunal determine that the Applicant has not made a relevant application. Accordingly the Tribunal have good reason to believe that it would not be appropriate to accept the application and reject the application in terms of rule 8 (1)(c) of the Tribunal Rules.

summary: The Tribunal rejected the application because the applicant did not provide the requested information. The Tribunal had good reason to believe that it would not be appropriate to accept the application.
The homeowner filed an application that was subsequently rejected by the tribunal. The applicant failed to provide requested information despite multiple reminders.
key_quote: The Applicant has not provided the information requested and has had ample opportunity to do so.

summary: The homeowner complained that the property factor was not entitled to charge him for common repairs and maintenance. The tribunal decided to reject the application because they had good reason to believe it would not be appropriate to accept it.
key_quote: The basis of the homeowner’s complaint was that the property factor was not entitled to charge him in respect of common repairs and maintenance because the feudal system was abolished by the Title Conditions (Scotland) Act 2003.

summary: The homeowner's application was rejected because they failed to respond to the Tribunal's requests for further information. The Tribunal determined that the dispute had been resolved, leading to the rejection.
key_quote: Since no response has been received to any of these letters, I consider that the dispute to which the application relates has been resolved and I have therefore decided to reject your application under Rule 8 (b) of the 2017 rules.

summary: The homeowner's application was rejected because they did not respond to requests for further information. The tribunal decided the dispute had been resolved or was not appropriate for acceptance.
key_quote: I consider that the dispute to which the application relates has been resolved or it is not appropriate to accept the application and I have therefore decided to reject your application under Rule 8 (b) and (c) of the 2017 rules.

summary: The homeowner filed a complaint, but failed to respond to the Tribunal's requests for further information. The Tribunal considered the matter resolved and rejected the application.
key_quote: As no response has been received to the said letters dated 27th November 2018 and 15th January 2019 and the said email dated 25th February 2019 the Tribunal believe that the dispute has been resolved and reject the application in terms of rule 8 (1)(b) of the Tribunal Rules.

summary: The homeowner filed an application with the tribunal. However, the tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner did not respond to requests for information and the tribunal believed the dispute had been resolved.
key_quote: As no response has been received to the said letters dated 10th January 2019 and 19th February 2019 the Tribunal believe that the dispute has been resolved and reject the application in terms of rule 8(10(b) of the Tribunal Rules.

summary: The homeowner's application was rejected. The reason for the rejection was that the information needed to proceed with the application was requested, but there was no response, therefore the dispute was considered resolved.

The homeowner complained that Oak Tree Housing Association failed to ensure the common stair was cleaned. The tribunal rejected the application, finding it was frivolous as the issue related to Oak Tree's role as a landlord, not a property factor.
key_quote: I have concluded that your application is vexatious or frivolous, and I have therefore decided to reject your application under Section 18 (2) (a) of the Act.

summary: The homeowner complained about the breakdown of gardening costs and scope of works. The tribunal allowed the application to be withdrawn as the parties reached an agreement.
key_quote: The tribunal will make no order nor any findings regarding any alleged breaches of the property factors Code of Conduct for  Property Factors

summary: The homeowner complained that the factor failed to provide inspection reports, the cost of the inspections was included in the management fee even though the Factor was unable to prove that all inspections had been carried out. The Tribunal found the Factor in breach of the Code for failing to provide information about the inspections and for failing to respond in a timely manner.
key_quote: The Tribunal did not accept Mr Gilchrist’s evidence that the Factor’s employee would definitely have carried out the site inspections. There was simply no substantive evidence to support such an assertion.

summary: The homeowner made an application to the tribunal. However, the applicant did not provide the requested information to process the application, leading to its rejection.
key_quote: The Applicant has not provided the information requested and has had sufficient opportunity to do so.

summary: The homeowner filed an application with the tribunal. The tribunal requested additional information from the applicant, which was not provided. Consequently, the tribunal rejected the application.
key_quote: The Tribunal rejects the application by the applicant dated 9th February 2020 being an application under section 17(1) of the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011.

summary: The applicant submitted an application to the Tribunal regarding an alleged failure to comply with the Letting Agent Code of Practice. The Tribunal rejected the application because the applicant failed to provide required information and documentation.
key_quote: The basis of the decision is that the Applicant has failed to comply with Rule 5 and Rule 95 and Section 48 of the 2014 Act.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application, but failed to provide evidence of notifying the property factor as required by the 2011 Act and the Tribunal's request for information.  The Tribunal rejected the application.
key_quote: The Legal Member therefore determines that the application cannot be accepted. The application is rejected on that basis.

summary: The applicant's applications were rejected. The Tribunal requested further information from the applicant, but no response was received.
The homeowner submitted an application to the Tribunal. The Tribunal rejected the application because the applicant failed to comply with the rules and provide the necessary information.
key_quote: The basis of the decision is that the Applicant has failed to comply with Rule 5 and Rule 43.

summary: The homeowner complained about the property factor's actions, including false statements, failure to respond to complaints, and inappropriate communication. The tribunal upheld the complaints related to OSP4, OSP10, OSP12 and Sections 2.2 and 2.7 of the Property Factors Code of Conduct, awarding the homeowner compensation for distress.
key_quote: The view of the Tribunal was that the statement in the property factors’ email of 18 February 2023 that the Fire and Rescue Service “now have their own key to the fire alarm system” was clearly untrue and that it had been made deliberately.

summary: The homeowner complained about the arrangements for general meetings of homeowners, specifically whether they could be conducted in any manner other than in person. The Tribunal made a Property Factor Enforcement Order requiring the factor to hold meetings in person unless the deeds permit virtual meetings.
key_quote: It undertakes that general meetings will not be held virtually until and unless the Deeds of the development permit such arrangements.

summary: The homeowner submitted two applications concerning failure to comply with the Code.  The Tribunal rejected the applications because the homeowner failed to provide required documentation and evidence of notification to the Property Factor.
key_quote: The Legal Member therefore determines that the application cannot be accepted. The application is rejected on that basis.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application to the Tribunal. The Tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner failed to provide required information, including evidence of notifying the Property Factor of the issues.
key_quote: The Legal Member therefore determines that the application cannot be accepted. The application is rejected on that basis.

summary: The applicant made an application under section 17(1) of the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011. The tribunal rejected the application.

The homeowner submitted an application to the Tribunal but failed to provide evidence of notifying the Property Factor of their concerns, as required by the 2011 Act. The Tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner did not provide the necessary information.
key_quote: The Applicant has failed to provide evidence of notification to the Property Factor in terms of Section 17 (3) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The applicant submitted an application, but failed to provide requested information to the Tribunal. The Tribunal rejected the application because of the lack of response and documentation.
key_quote: The Tribunal rejects the application by the Applicant dated 2nd August 2023 being an application under section 17(1) of the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011 (hereinafter referred to as ‘The Act’).

summary: The homeowner submitted an application, but failed to provide the required evidence of notification to the property factor. The tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner did not follow the required procedures.
key_quote: The Applicant has failed to provide evidence of notification to the Property Factor in terms of Section 17 (3) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner's application was rejected because they failed to provide evidence of notifying the property factor about their concerns. The applicant was also asked to provide further information but did not respond.
key_quote: The Applicant has failed to provide evidence of notification to the Property Factor in terms of Section 17 (3) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application alleging the Property Factor had not complied with the Code of Conduct. The Tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner did not provide requested information and failed to notify the factor of their concerns.
key_quote: The Legal Member therefore determines that the application cannot be accepted. The application is rejected on that basis.

summary: The homeowner filed an application but failed to provide evidence of notifying the property factor of their concerns. The tribunal rejected the application because the required information was not provided.
key_quote: The Applicant has failed to provide evidence of notification to the Property Factor in terms of Section 17 (3) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The applicant's application was rejected because they failed to provide the tribunal with the required information. The tribunal had requested further details to clarify the application's validity.
key_quote: The Tribunal rejects the application by the applicant dated 20th February 2024, being an application under section 17(1) of the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application but failed to provide required documentation and proof of notifying the property factor of the complaint. The tribunal rejected the application due to the homeowner's failure to comply with procedural rules and legislation.
key_quote: The Homeowner has failed to provide the information and documents required by Rule 43 of the Rules and Section 17 of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner submitted two applications alleging the property factor failed to comply with the Code of Conduct. The tribunal rejected the applications because the homeowner failed to provide required information and evidence of notification to the property factor.
key_quote: The Applicant has failed to provide evidence of notification to the Property Factor in terms of Section 17 (3) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner complained about roof repair activities. The tribunal determined the homeowner did not exhaust the property factor's complaints procedure and the application was premature.
key_quote: The Tribunal find and determine that the email of 7 June 2023 constituted the first formal complaint under Step 1 of the Respondent’s complaints procedure.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application to the Tribunal but failed to provide required information, including evidence of notification to the Property Factor. The Tribunal rejected the application because it was not lodged in the prescribed manner.
key_quote: The Applicant has failed to provide evidence of notification to the Property Factor in terms of Section 17 (3) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application to the Tribunal. However, the homeowner failed to provide required evidence of notification to the Property Factor and the application was rejected.
key_quote: The Applicant has failed to provide evidence of notification to the Property Factor in terms of Section 17 (3) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner submitted an incomplete application and failed to provide required information, including a notification to the property factor as required by the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011. The Tribunal rejected the application due to the lack of required information.
key_quote: The Tribunal rejects the application by the applicant sent to the Tribunal by email dated 18th March 2024, being an application under section 17(1) of the Property Factors (Scotland) Act 2011.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application, but failed to provide evidence of notification to the Property Factor. The tribunal rejected the application.
key_quote: The Legal Member therefore determines that the application cannot be accepted. The application is rejected on that basis.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application to the Tribunal but failed to provide requested information.  The Tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner did not comply with the rules.
key_quote: The basis of the decision is that the Applicant has failed to comply with Rule 5 of the Rules and Section 17 (3) (a) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner did not provide the necessary information requested by the Tribunal to demonstrate that they had notified the property factor of their complaint. The Tribunal rejected the application because the homeowner failed to comply with the rules.
key_quote: The basis of the decision is that the Applicant has failed to comply with Rule 5 of the Rules and Section 17 (3) (a) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner's application was rejected because they failed to provide required documentation and evidence of prior notification to the property factor, as mandated by the relevant regulations. The Tribunal determined the application was incomplete and couldn't be accepted.
key_quote: The basis of the decision is that the Applicant has failed to comply with Rule 5 of the Rules and Section 17 (3) (a) of the 2011 Act.

summary: The homeowner complained about incorrect allocation of costs on invoices. The tribunal upheld the complaint, finding that the property factor had misinterpreted the Deed of Conditions, leading to improper payment requests.
key_quote: The Tribunal upheld the complaint under Section 3.1. The view of the Tribunal was that the property factors had made an honest mistake, but that, nevertheless, improper, or at least incorrect, payment requests were made as a result of the property factors failing to allocate costs correctly.

summary: The homeowner submitted an application, but failed to specify which paragraphs of the Code the factor had not complied with.  The Tribunal rejected the application.
key_quote: The Applicant has failed to specify in the application form, the paragraphs of the Code which she considers the Property Factor has not complied with.
